page.title: 14Oast Houses and Agriculture
page.content: In this area there is evidence that the traditional oast house is no longer in use for hop drying, but they are being converted to dwellings. The hop acerage has declined greatly and the demand for drying facilities decreases. The presence of such residences provides not only evidence of changing agriculture, but also illustrates the impact of residential development on the area. The converted oast in Henwood Green Road is completely surrounded by houses not farmland. In 1878 there were 40,000 acres of hops in Kent, a total of 7000 oasts. Today, in the 12 square kilometre area there are no hops and only 2 farms with oasts not converted, these are used only as barns.
